{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3325605,"name":"Sean Smith","username":"s_smith6933","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/3ab097/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-06T14:58:25.520Z","cooked":"

My team is having an odd thing happen with our robot occasionally, where we’ll be driving around and then suddenly the robot disables itself. After taking a look at the log file in the driver station software, we saw that the latency jumped really high and the measurement of CAN percentage just stopped drawing any line, and all of this happened right before it disabled itself. We could tell pretty quickly that it wasn’t an issue of radio power- because connection with robot was reestablished within a second after this occurred. Additionally, because this problem only seems to happen when the robot is in motion, we figured it was likely to be caused by a loose RJ45 connection between the RIO and radio. Our team purchased a REV radio power module this season, and we also have an ethernet switch onboard to service our two limelights, meaning between the RIO and radio, there are 5 RJ45 connections (see the attached drawing). This feels like a lot, and so I was hoping to hear if any teams are using POE switches on their robots, and if anyone has suggestions for models. This would eliminate two of the connectors between the RIO and radio, and allow for one less connector between the switch and each limelight. Also, if anyone has advice for a better way to lay this all out in the first place- we’re all ears!

Screenshot 2024-03-06 at 9.48.54 AM1604×1122 87.2 KB

How is the switch powered? This sounds like it’s rebooting.

You might also want to check if the radio is near an RFI source, such as the PCM/PH.

s_smith6933:

using POE switches on their robots, and if anyone has suggestions for models. This would eliminate two of the connectors between the RIO and radio

If you’re proposing to power the radio from a POE switch, I don’t think that would be legal.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-03-06T16:00:40.544Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":143,"readers_count":142,"score":38.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":457541,"topic_slug":"robot-comms-latency-issues","display_username":"Gavin Matthews","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38743,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming mentor, Team 2102, RI, CSA (he/him)"},"post_url":"/t/robot-comms-latency-issues/457541/3","custom_user_title":"Programming mentor, Team 2102, RI, CSA (he/him)","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3325686,"name":"Joseph Walters","username":"Jwal","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jwal/{size}/228161_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-06T16:13:37.958Z","cooked":"

Using active POE you might see commonly used in industry, you are correct. All of those devices use higher voltage AC to transmit power, exceeding the 24V threshold deems FRC legal.

There are passive POE switches that exist, mostly from Alibaba and similar vendors.

OP if this is your desired path, just know few have treaded this direction and you will be somewhat of a trailblazer.

Additionally - you will NOT want passive POE on all your switch connected components, like the roborio, your laptop if you plan to tether via Ethernet, etc…so you likely need a traditional non POE switch as well for those devices.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-03-06T16:14:59.749Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":127,"readers_count":126,"score":35.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":457541,"topic_slug":"robot-comms-latency-issues","display_username":"Joseph Walters","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":38743,"username":"bovlb","name":"Gavin Matthews","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bovlb/{size}/167232_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63541,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/robot-comms-latency-issues/457541/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3325742,"name":"Gavin Matthews","username":"bovlb","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bovlb/{size}/167232_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-06T16:42:38.070Z","cooked":"
Jwal:

Using active POE […] you are correct. […] There are passive POE switches that exist

R616 requires that the radio be powered from either the CTR VRM or a REV RPM. Passive POE from a switch would not qualify.

s_smith6933:

RJ45 connections

There are better or worse varieties of these. For example, we had a Rev radio power module that felt like insertion bottomed out before the reassuring click. Students didn’t push that little extra to the click and you can imagine if we won or lost that match.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-03-06T17:35:01.785Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":91,"readers_count":90,"score":18.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":457541,"topic_slug":"robot-comms-latency-issues","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/robot-comms-latency-issues/457541/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3325845,"name":"Joseph Walters","username":"Jwal","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jwal/{size}/228161_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-06T17:34:27.946Z","cooked":"

Fair enough! You are correct.

So OPs idea of a passive POE switch is really only viable for “other” devices on the robot like coprocessors…no core functionality could hook up to a passive POE switch (cannot plug in a laptop, robot radio, roborio)

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-03-06T17:34:27.946Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":87,"readers_count":86,"score":17.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":457541,"topic_slug":"robot-comms-latency-issues","display_username":"Joseph Walters","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":38743,"username":"bovlb","name":"Gavin Matthews","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bovlb/{size}/167232_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63541,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/robot-comms-latency-issues/457541/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3325879,"name":"Joshua J","username":"thatnameistaken","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/57b2e6/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-06T18:03:52.373Z","cooked":"
bovlb:

R616 requires that the radio be powered from either the CTR VRM or a REV RPM. Passive POE from a switch would not qualify.

If it’s truly passive, that’s not quite why it wouldn’t work. It’d still be powered by the VRM in that scenario, it just wouldn’t be the only load on the 12V 2A channel - unless you can find a network switch with separate power inputs for and POE out and the actual switch itself.

s_smith6933:

Also, if anyone has advice for a better way to lay this all out in the first place- we’re all ears!

Just qualify for champs and the new radio they’re rolling out there will clean that right up. RoboRIO to the radio, both Limelights to the radio, and the radio is powered directly by the PDP/PDH (with passive POE out to the Limelights).*

More seriously, what you’re doing right now is exactly** what I’d recommend with the current control system as a CSA. If you consider your cameras mission critical, the best way to do things is to use a switch to avoid using the faulty second Ethernet port on the radio, and anecdotally the REV Radio Power Module is more robust at low voltages than the VRM (and works with more reliable Ethernet cables); you’re doing all of that, so good on you. In theory, it’d be nice to have a POE switch instead of two injectors for the cameras, but in practice passive POE switches that run on 12V don’t really exist, and if they did, you’d need one with two unpowered ports; most have just one.

*If you do qualify for champs, make sure to remove the REV RPM from your system if you want to use the new radio POE out for the cameras. 18V won’t play nice with them. Fortunately, the new radio and the Limelight both have internal power regulators, so being powered directly by the PDP/PDH isn’t only okay, it’s actually recommended.

** I can’t recommend the orange REV POE cables, though. I see the data line fail on them far more than I’m comfortable with. At least in your case, it’s not bringing your whole robot down, but I’d try to source a different injector for the cameras if you could. If that’s not an option, as annoying as it is, I’d recommend separate power and standard Ethernet instead of the REV cable. If you insist on using them anyway, avoid tight bends at all costs and strain relieve well.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-03-06T18:12:17.454Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":2,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":80,"readers_count":79,"score":41.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":457541,"topic_slug":"robot-comms-latency-issues","display_username":"Joshua J","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19116,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"CSA | Drive Coach (2191)"},"post_url":"/t/robot-comms-latency-issues/457541/8","custom_user_title":"CSA | Drive Coach (2191)","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3326001,"name":"Gavin Matthews","username":"bovlb","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bovlb/{size}/167232_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-06T19:29:24.521Z","cooked":"
thatnameistaken:

If it’s truly passive, that’s not quite why it wouldn’t work. It’d still be powered by the VRM in that scenario, it just wouldn’t be the only load on the 12V 2A channel - unless you can find a network switch with separate power inputs for and POE out and the actual switch itself.

I could see the argument that a switch with POE is just a bus connecting the VRM to the radio, but as I understand it, passive POE switches are typically powered from the same input, and even if it weren’t you wouldn’t be allowed to power any other POE devices off the switch, rendering it somewhat pointless to have a POE switch. So you would have a setup that would have trouble getting past inspection that confers no real benefit.

If you have a lot of passive POE devices on the robot, then it might make sense to use a multiport passive POE injector together with a regular switch, but obviously not for the radio.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-03-06T19:29:24.521Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":64,"readers_count":63,"score":22.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":457541,"topic_slug":"robot-comms-latency-issues","display_username":"Gavin Matthews","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.amazon.com/Passive-Injection-Module-Ethernet-Injector/dp/B08BLFGWV2","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":3}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38743,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming mentor, Team 2102, RI, CSA (he/him)"},"post_url":"/t/robot-comms-latency-issues/457541/9","custom_user_title":"Programming mentor, Team 2102, RI, CSA (he/him)","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3326332,"name":"Sean Smith","username":"s_smith6933","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/3ab097/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-07T00:03:50.363Z","cooked":"

I appreciate all of the quick responses to this. It’s good to know that a low voltage POE switch is not an option- so we’ll work with what we’ve got. Thanks for the input everyone!

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-03-07T00:03:50.363Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":52,"readers_count":51,"score":15.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":457541,"topic_slug":"robot-comms-latency-issues","display_username":"Sean Smith","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56469,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"WPI '27"},"post_url":"/t/robot-comms-latency-issues/457541/10","custom_user_title":"WPI '27","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3326333,"name":"Sean Smith","username":"s_smith6933","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/3ab097/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-07T00:04:55.516Z","cooked":"
thatnameistaken:

** I can’t recommend the orange REV POE cables, though. I see the data line fail on them far more than I’m comfortable with. At least in your case, it’s not bringing your whole robot down, but I’d try to source a different injector for the cameras if you could. If that’s not an option, as annoying as it is, I’d recommend separate power and standard Ethernet instead of the REV cable. If you insist on using them anyway, avoid tight bends at all costs and strain relieve well.

This is very good to know, thanks for the warning. We’ll look into removing them from our system altogether.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-03-07T00:04:55.516Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":53,"readers_count":52,"score":10.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":457541,"topic_slug":"robot-comms-latency-issues","display_username":"Sean Smith","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56469,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"WPI '27"},"post_url":"/t/robot-comms-latency-issues/457541/11","custom_user_title":"WPI '27","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3326363,"name":"Jsteel","username":"Jsteel","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/9de053/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-07T00:44:12.532Z","cooked":"

This topic rapidly became about radio connections. We are having the exact same issue - short disables where the robot comes back enabled quickly. It appears to have nothing to do with the radio. We have had it happen both at home practice and at our week 1 event. At week 1, our FTA told us they never saw a blip on the radio at all. The problem was a blip on the Can network. We are still trying to figure this out.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-03-07T00:44:12.532Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":47,"readers_count":46,"score":14.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":457541,"topic_slug":"robot-comms-latency-issues","display_username":"Jsteel","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24050,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/robot-comms-latency-issues/457541/12","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3326369,"name":"NewtonCrosby","username":"NewtonCrosby","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/ed8c4c/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-07T00:58:55.852Z","cooked":"
s_smith6933:

… We could tell pretty quickly that it wasn’t an issue of radio power- because connection with robot was reestablished within a second after this occurred. Additionally, because this problem only seems to happen when the robot is in motion, we figured it was likely to be caused by a loose RJ45 connection between the RIO and radio. …

I would put my money on intermittent power to the D-Link.

I actually got so sidetracked by the POE discussion I forgot what this thread was about, oops!

@s_smith6933 It does sound like an Ethernet problem somewhere. If you can’t identify a loose cable, it may be worth swapping the cables out one at a time and seeing if the problem goes away; you could have a bad one. Power to the network switch is also a possibility, as they tend to reboot very quickly. Is it a barrel jack connector? If so, try hot glueing it in and see if the problem goes away.

Jsteel:

At week 1, our FTA told us they never saw a blip on the radio at all.

If the FMS log doesn’t have a radio disconnect, all that means is your radio’s wireless connection to the field remained good; the connection between your radio and RIO may have had blips (it could help if you post driver station logs). Follow the same advice as above (though the network switch bit only applies if you’re using one), and if you’re using the orange REV POE cable to power the radio, I’d start by seeing if you drop out when you wiggle that around.
